Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and maize is no exception. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes of biodiversity and for predicting the consequences of climate change and habitat loss. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that diet composition differs between all species—even pairs of species matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity is sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which species partition food resources. Understanding the mechanisms of niche partitioning is critical for predicting the consequences of climate change and habitat loss for biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, particularly for public health authorities, epidemiologists, and researchers. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is highly dynamic and regulated by a complex network of factors. Here we investigated the role of insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroblasts and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 silencing in human erythroblasts results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. The findings may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and for the treatment of anemia. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of anemia.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of plasma membrane ORAI channels. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic book phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 100-y-long period of global climate change that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of magnetic grains from the YDB sites is consistent with terrestrial Os in bulk samples from 5 sites in the United States and Belgium. The Os in the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania is likely terrestrial, and the spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling. The results also suggest that the YDB cooling is not a single event but rather a series of events. The impact-triggered cooling events may have contributed to the evolution of the Earth system.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. We also show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice leads to a more severe autoimmune disease than congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which are the basis of the beetle diet. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Our results suggest that PCWDEs enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of the number of models available to participants in a social-learning condition, and the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. Our results also highlight the importance of the working memory of participants in a social-learning condition.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk, but the underlying mechanism is not known. Here, we show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a key factor in understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. Our findings also suggest that the inner core nucleation mechanism is a general process in the crystallization of metallic systems. This process can be applied to the nucleation of other planets and stars. It may also be useful in the search for life in the universe.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of long-term marijuana use are unknown. We show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. Reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with addiction severity and craving. These findings highlight the importance of studying the effects of marijuana on the brain, and the need to develop effective treatment for marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining feature of our species, and the human brain is uniquely tuned to language. We therefore seek to understand how the human brain processes language. Here, we show that deep learning models can predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain, and that this predictive power correlates with model accuracy on a language task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the human brain’s processing of language. This approach could be extended to other domains of human cognition, including perception and memory. Such a “reverse-engineering” approach could reveal the computational principles that govern the human mind. It could also lead to computational models of the human mind that could be tested in the lab and in the wild.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a fundamental problem, but rather a consequence of the instability of the algorithms used to train deep networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result provides a classification theory of conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of deep learning in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment that has been cited as evidence for such a failure. The experiment’s design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon. The flaws are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its treatment has been the subject of much controversy. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been shown to infect the peripheral nervous system and cause sensory loss, and the disease is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a human pathogen that causes diffuse lepromatous leprosy. We also present a phylogeographic survey of leprosy patients and show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the MRCA than is M. leprae. These results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This knowledge may help to elucidate the mechanisms that underlie the evolution of the disease. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information science, which is the main field of application of entanglement. However, the connection between these two concepts is still poorly understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in quantum systems can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit. This result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical simulations. This work provides a new perspective on the connection between entanglement and thermodynamics and opens the way to the study of entanglement in interacting systems.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can spread by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by recurrent epidemics, which were likely caused by human ectoparasite vectors. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study contributes to our understanding of the history of plague and its vectors. It also provides a framework for future studies on the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not captured by brain size alone. This study shows that, relative to body size, brains of reptiles are smaller but have more neurons, resulting in lower neuronal densities. This pattern is reversed in birds and mammals, which have larger brains relative to body size but have lower neuron numbers. The evolution of brain neuronal density is associated with cognitive ability in birds and primates but not in other mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and induces severing in a mechanical torque-dependent manner. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF in severing actin networks and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for actin-based motility disorders.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is essential to understand the history of Madagascar and to study the genetic consequences of the settlement of Madagascar. This information will also be useful to study the genetic consequences of the recent climate change in Madagascar.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our results have implications for the design of social networks, the spread of emotions, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a short-lived molecule that is translated into proteins. The mRNA sequence is often modified after transcription, but the impact of these modifications on translation is not well understood. We reconstituted the bacterial translation system and human cells to test the effects of mRNA modifications on translation. We find that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can modestly alter translation speed and the reaction rate of a near-cognate amino acid–transfer RNA complex. Our results suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on translation, which may be important for mRNA stability and function. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the impact of mRNA modifications on translation. (Show more)
The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers remain unclear. We use a model of the energetic constraints on body size to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is consistent with the evolution of a smaller minimum size and a larger maximum size in aquatic mammals than on land. This model provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication suggests that the virus has evolved to replicate more efficiently at the cool nasal cavity temperature than at core body temperature. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C, which correlates with higher expression of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. Genetic deficiency of MAVS or the type I IFN receptor in infected airway cells permitted higher levels of viral replication, particularly at 37 °C, and partially rescued the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies for the treatment of the common cold. The bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients and other individuals. It is a master of surface interactions, and its ability to colonize and cause disease is highly dependent on its ability to attach to surfaces. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to detect surfaces on short timescales. This mechanochemical process results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which in turn can stimulate additional virulence factors. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial mechanosensors and the mechanisms by which bacteria sense and respond to surfaces. They also have implications for the development of new antibiotics that target bacterial surface interactions. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water worldwide. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. The current study demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is circulating in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. This study also highlights the importance of a “One Health” approach to study the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. The findings have implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and the need for a more proactive approach to study the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. This study also provides a baseline for future studies to monitor the circulation of SARS-CoV-2 in deer. The results also highlight the need for a more proactive approach to study the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of large dams, and the solutions that are needed. We find that the environmental and social problems are caused by the industry itself, not by governments. We also find that the industry needs to incorporate climate change into its decision-making process and that the industry needs to be more transparent about the costs and benefits of its projects. Finally, we propose a new approach to hydropower that can be used to move the industry toward sustainability.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but it is clear that the immune system plays a significant role in AD pathogenesis. In this study, we identify a unique inflammatory profile in neurons that are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ. We show that neurons are capable of producing a variety of potent inflammatory factors, even in the absence of extracellular Aβ plaques and cell death. These findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ within neurons may be a significant contributor to AD pathogenesis, and may provide a potential therapeutic target. This study provides insight into the complex interplay between neurons and the immune system in AD. It also highlights the importance of intraneuronal Aβ accumulation in the development of AD pathology.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. This is the earliest known period of chicken exploitation in the world. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. We further argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of chicken domestication and its spread to Europe. It also sheds light on the role of the Hellenistic period in the spread of domesticated animals from the Near East to Europe. (Show more)

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding the principles of protein folding. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two distinct steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower formation of a distinct intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway and is the site of three destabilizing mutations. The intermediate is also the site of two of the three steps of the folding of a smaller protein. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This study provides a deeper understanding of the folding of large proteins. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism of RNA interference in bacteria. However, the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to recognize di- and triphosphorylated RNA as substrates, also prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria adapt to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that affects millions of people worldwide. Despite the advances in the treatment of sepsis, the mortality rate remains high. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that the arginine-to-citrulline metabolic conversion could be a promising strategy to restore immune function during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study could also lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of other inflammatory diseases. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with no external control parameter reach a critical state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, which limit its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. It also provides a general framework for exploring the properties of other materials. This work is expected to advance the development of diamond-based devices and applications. (Show more)

The discovery of antifungal peptides is a major advance in the field of plant disease resistance. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a better understanding of the antifungal activity of plant cysteine-rich peptides and their potential as a new class of fungicides. This study also provides a starting point for the development of a new class of fungicides. This work will be useful for the development of a new class of fungicides.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical interface that mediates the transfer of genetic material between individuals. Although the male–female interface is well characterized, the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive success is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome after mating and that these proteins support sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of broad interest to the broader scientific community. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. The A1 domain is conformationally sensitive, and mutations in A1 cause bleeding disorders. We show that force application to VWF switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD mutations. The force-dependent switching of the A1 domain is a general mechanism for activating receptor−ligand interactions. The results are important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD and for understanding the mechanism of action of VWF in hemostasis. The results also provide a mechanism for the action of VWF in hemostasis. The results are important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD and for understanding the mechanism of action of VWF in hemostasis.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. We find that the human virome is associated with many diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and autism. This study will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for decades. The most widely accepted estimate of surface temperature in the Archean era, the period of Earth’s earliest history, is 70 ± 15 °C. This estimate, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing ancient surface temperatures based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by two gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the BK channel’s unique properties and may help in the development of BK channel modulators. They also provide a possible mechanism for the BK channel’s slow C-type inactivation. Our findings may be extended to other K+ channels that lack activation gates. Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with an estimated 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The Plasmodium parasite exploits the host cell’s biophysical properties to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen EBA175 alters the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a potential target for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, which limit its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain, which can be used to control its electronic and optical properties. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. It also provides a general framework for exploring the properties of other materials. This work can lead to new applications of diamond and other materials. It can also lead to new insights into the properties of materials. This work is expected to advance the development of materials science and technology.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. Our findings may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in low humidity regions. This study also provides a platform to study the impact of dry air on other respiratory viral infections. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how left-hemispheric brain activity varies during the formation of phrase structures. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This merge operation was equally applied to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the construction of meaning.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates a wide range of processes, including cell fate specification, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled (FZD) and the effector Axin. Axin is a dual-kinase that can either activate or inhibit the Wnt signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that the two forms of Axin have different functions in the Wnt pathway. This study provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by mutations in these genes.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this stimulation-induced eating is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which in turn inhibit dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, VTA GABA neurons, or peri-LH GABA neurons in the locus coeruleus. Finally, we found that stimulation-induced eating is not blocked by lesions of LH neurons in the VTA or the substantia nigra. These results suggest that the LH GABA neurons project to the VTA, where they inhibit dopamine neurons, which in turn inhibit dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. This circuit may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This is the first study to characterize the brain circuitry that may promote overeating.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil would revolutionize agriculture. However, the symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria is inefficient and is limited to a few plant species. Here, we developed a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to increase nitrogen fixation in agriculture, which is currently limited by the inefficient symbiosis. It could also be used to develop nitrogen-fixing plants for other applications, such as bioremediation. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a critical tool for forest monitoring, but they rarely reach the communities most directly affected by deforestation in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because the program was randomly assigned to only a small fraction of the communities in the region. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy and are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its hearing to its self-manufactured web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of its threads, which is used to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider’s web is flexible and can be regenerated after damage, allowing it to be easily adjusted to the spider’s needs. The spider’s outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function provides unique features for studying acoustic sensing and design of acoustic flow detectors. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic sensors and actuators. It also provides a unique model for studying the regenerative sensing of the web. The spider’s hearing system is a good example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function. It is a promising model for studying the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic sensors and actuators.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuel and major anthropogenic aerosols. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The need for a safe and efficacious vaccine remains urgent. We report the design, construction, and evaluation of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. This engineered protein can be presented on a designed VLP, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD protein could be used in a vaccine to provide protection against SARS-CoV-2. This engineered RBD protein could be used in a vaccine to provide protection against SARS-CoV-2.

The role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development has been studied in detail in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster and the mouse mouse. However, the zebrafish Danio rerio is a powerful model to study the role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk are activated by ALKALs, a family of secreted proteins that are expressed in the zebrafish embryo. We further show that ALKALs are required for zebrafish neural crest development. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/Ltk family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings contribute to our understanding of the role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development and may lead to the development of ALK/Ltk inhibitors as a treatment for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been poorly understood due to a lack of genomic data from the earliest stages of its evolution. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y ago. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be critical for understanding the origins of this devastating pathogen. This work also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in the study of infectious diseases and their impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also suggest that men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity may be a target for intervention.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can maximize SOC storage on grassland-derived Mollisols remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil organic matter and microbial biomass, such as incorporating legumes and manure into annual cropping systems, can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil. However, these practices did not increase mineral-associated SOC, a fraction that is more resistant to decomposition and loss through erosion. Soil health management practices that increase the abundance of soil microbes that decompose crop residues and manure, such as rotational grazing of pastures, can increase mineral-associated SOC and decrease the rate of SOC loss. These results highlight the importance of soil health management practices that increase the abundance of microbes that decompose crop residues and manure in increasing SOC storage on Mollisols. This study provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices that can increase SOC storage on grassland-derived soils. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses was used to identify the top 12 priority viruses for further investigation. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be useful for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present genome data from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of these individuals indicates that men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that women also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. The global spread of infectious diseases requires a global response. To achieve this, we must understand the regional pathogen landscape and the surveillance of emerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA from patients with undifferentiated febrile illness in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Our results highlight the feasibility of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can help to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and the surveillance of emerging pathogens. This will enable a global response to infectious diseases.

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous fashion, with the lagging strand template being synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a discontinuous fashion. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical to the synthesis of the lagging strand template as it dictates the rate of synthesis. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on lagging strand synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA polymerases, but the activity of such polymerases is limited to a few specific reactions. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold, and even synthesize a functional tRNA. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can serve as a primitive RNA polymerase in the laboratory, allowing the reconstruction of the RNA world. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Finally, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic fortunes of neighborhoods.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a mechanism to control copper toxicity through the secretion of a family of isocyanide compounds derived from the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster. This study demonstrates that xanthocillin isocyanide compounds bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The copper-chelating properties of xanthocillin isocyanides were demonstrated in vitro and in vivo, and the ability of xanthocillin isocyanides to mediate interactions between Aspergillus and competing microbes was shown. These results suggest that fungal xanthocillin isocyanide compounds may play a role in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This study highlights the existence of fungal natural products that bind and impact cellular copper content and may have implications for the role of copper in fungal biology and interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with high formation temperatures (>870 °C) and is indicative of silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The presence of amorphous silica, salts, and oxides in the same sample is consistent with multiple aqueous fluid infiltrations, each with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite, magnetite, and amorphous silica in a single sample is consistent with a single sediment source, the crater wall/rim/central peak.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance traits to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also highlight the importance of the geographic distribution of frost events in shaping the evolutionary strategies of plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. We found that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells and that the development of colitis required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings provide insight into the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, different clinical phenotypes, and different causes of death. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the absence of symptoms. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new treatments. This method will also enable rapid production of motor neuron-like cells from living patients with other neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson’s disease. This will accelerate research into these diseases and lead to the development of new treatments.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen colonization and development. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the composition of the tick microbiota and enhances the colonization of Anaplasma. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of the gut microbiota, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how pathogens influence the microbiota of arthropod vectors to enhance colonization. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary transition in the avian lineage, but the diversity of early members is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the short-tailed bird group and adds important information about the evolution of the avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis also highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian body plan. The mosaic evolution of the avian body plan is a major challenge for understanding the evolution of the modern avian body plan.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of color patterns to avoid detection by predators and prey. One such pattern is the presence of blue-green tissues, which is found in many species of amphibians. This phenomenon is called chlorosis, and it is thought to be the result of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of amphibians, and that the mechanism of biliverdin accumulation is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of chlorosis and introduces a new function for a serpin.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with increased proliferation, metastasis, and resistance to therapy. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes tumorigenesis are not fully understood. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), a mitochondrial m6A demethylase, which in turn increases expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and maintenance. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, which in turn promotes BCSC growth, proliferation, and tumorigenicity. These findings provide insight into the role of ALKBH5 in breast cancer biology and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation in the history of book production. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by analysis of the extracted proteins by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from a single manuscript. The results suggest that the production of tissue-thin parchment did not necessarily require the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the extinction and the rapid recovery of biodiversity are well constrained by the stratigraphy of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb dates of detrital zircon from five volcanic ash beds. The age model is refined by the identification of a carbon cycle perturbation that occurred at the time of the extinction. The carbon cycle perturbation is followed by a rapid recovery of the carbon cycle, but the link between the carbon cycle and the extinction is not yet resolved. The timing of the carbon cycle perturbation and the recovery of the carbon cycle are important for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses. The age model for the extinction is the basis for a refined evaluation of the extinction and recovery dynamics.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα remains unknown. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most prevalent mutation in the currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results may help to inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our findings highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of the disease and its consequences.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are widely used in chemistry. In this paper, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, chemical hardness and electronegativity, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is of great importance for the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. It also provides a new perspective on the chemical behavior of atoms.
