Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can reduce fire activity and mitigate warming. This is especially true under lower emission scenarios, which are more likely in the future. Our results highlight the importance of human demography in shaping the future fire regime and the carbon cycle. This is especially important for understanding the role of fire in climate change mitigation and adaptation.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most successful interactions in nature. The symbionts of the squid Euprymna scolopes, the bioluminescent bacterium Vibrio fischeri, have evolved a complex strategy to survive in the host’s crypts, where they are exposed to a hostile environment. We show here that the squid regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to the bacteria at night, when the bacteria are most vulnerable. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modifies the environment of the crypts. This glycan-mediated regulation of the symbiotic environment may be a general strategy for animal hosts to control the activities of their symbiotic communities. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the evolution of symbiosis. (Show more)

The study of text data has become a central component of many fields, from social science to medicine. However, the analysis of text data is often difficult because of the large number of documents and the variety of topics. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, which have been used to model the structure of language. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains and can be extended to other types of data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease spread across Europe. We show that this assumption is not supported by the historical record. Instead, we find that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from rodent reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium, which were delayed by several years. This finding challenges the current understanding of the history of the plague pandemic and suggests that the spread of the disease was more complex than previously thought. It also highlights the importance of climate variability in the spread of the disease. (Show more)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting a wide range of asteroid species in the Northeast Pacific Ocean. The disease is characterized by rapid tissue degradation and is associated with a densovirus. Here, we show that the densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and that it can be transmitted between asteroids. This study provides evidence that the virus is the cause of the disease and that it is highly contagious. This information will be useful for the development of control measures.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and culture. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west, and from the highlands to the coast. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the history and the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It will be useful for the understanding of the origin of the Malagasy people and the settlement of Madagascar. It will also be useful for the study of the human history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. The RNA also interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This work provides insight into the mechanism of action of dual-function RNAs. It also demonstrates the importance of the translation function of the RNA in the regulation of carbon utilization. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We propose a method to convert the original crop expert data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting crop condition index is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that the index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network can be used to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop conditions, which can be used to improve agricultural decision-making and food security.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, it is unclear how the brain maintains information over seconds and minutes. Here we propose a model of memory that relies on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to minutes. This model provides a framework for understanding how the brain maintains information over time. It also provides a computational basis for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because it occurred in the past and is still ongoing in many lineages. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the rate of molecular evolution in plastid genomes is a good proxy for the degree of functional reduction. This model can be used to infer the evolutionary history of the plastid genome in the course of the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. It can also be used to predict the evolutionary trajectories of the genomes of other organelle genomes. This model can be used to predict the evolutionary trajectories of the genomes of other organelle genomes.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of the impact of anthropogenic climate change on regional climate extremes. This study is timely, as the Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 °C above preindustrial temperatures. It is important to quantify the risks associated with such a goal.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. The discovery of quasicrystals in meteorites and in the laboratory has led to a revolution in our understanding of the structure of solids. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory and in meteorites and the discovery of quasicrystals in the environment. This discovery also demonstrates that quasicrystals can be discovered in the environment and that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals. This discovery has implications for the search for new quasicrystal-forming systems and for the search for extraterrestrial quasicrystals.

The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The first step of this reaction, catalyzed by a single enzyme in plants and cyanobacteria, is well understood. However, the second step, catalyzed by a second enzyme in plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. Here, we show that the second enzyme is a subunit of a larger enzyme, and that the two enzymes are evolutionarily related. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction in photosynthesis. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides insights into the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of EAE. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities. We also find that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased, and that this increase is also very likely due to human activities. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a potential therapeutic target for autism. This study also provides a model system to study the role of forgetting in learning and memory. (Show more)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, but that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable. This work thus helps account for the tendency for news around the world to be predominantly negative, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content to reach a larger audience.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has been difficult to elucidate because of its dual role in store-operated Ca2+ entry and in store de-excitation. Here, we show that gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 can each be used to activate the CRAC channel, thus providing a means to study the physiological role of the CRAC channel in a controlled manner. Our results expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a means to study the physiological role of the CRAC channel in a controlled manner. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is highly specialized to maintain a sterile environment in the body to prevent infection. However, the immune system of bats is also vulnerable to viral infection, which is a major concern for the conservation of bats. In this study, we identified a protein, Myotis pilosus submandibular MTX (MPSMTX), which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat. MPSMTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) activity to inhibit the generation of LTB4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MPSMTX facilitates viral infection by inhibiting the antiviral immune response of the host. This study provides deeper insight into the immune system of bats and the potential of targeting MPSMTX as a therapeutic strategy to prevent viral infection in bats. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising cancer therapy. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and thus represents a promising metabolic cancer target. Here we report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of formate as a metabolic rescue in SHMT inhibitors, and for the use of B-cell lines in the cancer cell-line screen. They also provide a starting point for the development of SHMT inhibitors as cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The origin of the Ceratophyllum clade of aquatic angiosperms is poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant previously overlooked, shows that it is sister to Ceratophyllum and that it lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. This study also shows that the origin of the Ceratophyllum clade is younger than previously thought. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we find a substitution rate that is an order of magnitude lower than previously estimated. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The data presented here may also be of interest for archaeologists and anthropologists.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is seen across multiple measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and the presence of opioid prescriptions. The increase in pain prevalence for those born after 1950 is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a fundamental piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain by X-ray crystallography, which is the method of choice for structure determination. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex, providing insight into the reaction pathway and the role of the cofactor in the reaction. This approach can be extended to other systems, providing a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to patients, healthcare workers, and the global community.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most successful and widespread forms of symbiosis on Earth. The bacteria provide essential nutrients, while the hosts provide a suitable environment. In this study, we show that the animal host provides a single glycan at a specific time of day, which is essential for the maintenance of the symbiont population. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the environment of the symbiont’s habitat. This glycan-catabolizing activity is required for the acidification of the host epithelium, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, in which the host provides a single nutrient at a specific time of day, which is essential for the maintenance of the symbiont population. This nutrient is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the environment of the symbiont’s habitat. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. We tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed through a brief, online intervention. Teachers (n = 31) in three districts (Nteachers = 31; Nstudents = 1,682) were randomly assigned to receive the intervention or not. Evaluated at five middle schools in three districts, the intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has implications for the future of school discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the normal function of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from this study provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work also provides a comprehensive understanding of the impact of DNA alkylation on transcriptional fidelity. These findings will facilitate the development of DNA repair and mutagenesis assays for the study of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This work will also provide important mechanistic insights into the impact of DNA alkylation on transcriptional fidelity. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted conformational changes induced by cell receptors, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may help to explain why MERS-CoV causes severe pneumonia in humans, but not in other cell types.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and the global population is expected to increase by 2.5 billion by 2050. The food system also contributes to the burden of diet-related noncommunicable diseases, which are the leading cause of death worldwide. The food system can be made more sustainable by increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering outlet by 50% can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40% and decrease sales of meat meals by 15%. This approach could be used to make a significant contribution to the sustainability and health of the global population.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic environment that is constantly being remodeled by the cell to engage the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique among coronavirus accessory proteins. The structure reveals a dimerization interface specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may mediate immune suppression and evasion. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. They also provide a foundation for the development of antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis. We also show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. Finally, we show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of endothelin-1 (ET-1). These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. It arises when we have a large dataset and wish to find the strongest associations. This is a challenge because we have to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The methods are illustrated with an analysis of the relationship between the human genome and the distribution of wealth in the world. The analysis shows that the genome is not a major determinant of wealth.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are critical for the development of the zebrafish eye. Here, we show that the zebrafish genome encodes three genes that encode ligands for Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and for the maintenance of the adult body coloration. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model system for the study of the function of orphan RTKs in the development of other organs. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in T2D has been reported, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the nuclear protein Pax6 was down-regulated in STING-βKO β-cells, and its nuclear localization was lost. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the development of STING-based therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the causative agents of annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The atheroprone environment, including disturbed flow, oxidative stress, and inflammation, is a critical factor in the development of atherosclerosis. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the atheroprone environment regulation of vascular homeostasis remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone environment is a critical mechanism in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Our study provides a molecular basis for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis and identifies YAP/TAZ as a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a new perspective for the development of athero-protective drugs. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and this trend is expected to continue. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires, and show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the importance of reducing fire risk to ecosystems and economies, and suggest that actions to reduce human-started wildfire ignitions should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic outcomes of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can shorten the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma VL loss. Our results provide insights into the within-host dynamics of ZIKV and can be used to guide the development of antiviral therapies. This work can also be used to assess the impact of ZIKV on the population dynamics of the virus. This information can be used to guide the development of control strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. One of the most conspicuous symptoms of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is the mass mortality of corals during heat waves, a phenomenon known as coral bleaching. While the symptoms of bleaching are well-known, the underlying causes remain unclear. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world. This will be crucial to ensure the conservation of one of the most valuable and diverse ecosystems on Earth.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In all animals, the epithelium is also the site of tumorigenesis. Here, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study identifies a mechanism that may be relevant to the development of intestinal tumors in humans. It also provides a model to study the interplay between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients relapse. We found that chemotherapy treatment of breast cancer cells enhanced the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1. ROR1 expression was enriched in breast cancer cells that were enriched for cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. We also found that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, cirmtuzumab may be a promising agent for the treatment of breast cancer.

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in Earth science. The onset of deglaciation is often linked to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a change in ocean circulation and climate. We show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions, coincident with the onset of deglaciation, plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a change in Southern Hemisphere climate. This finding provides a unique link between the timing of deglaciation and the stratosphere, and it has important implications for our understanding of the timing and causes of the last deglaciation. It also has implications for the timing of the next deglaciation. (The full version is in the PNAS journal archives.)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts, despite their importance for biodiversity and food security. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and to identify areas where fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security. Our analysis highlights the importance of inland fisheries for food security in regions where alternative sources of animal protein are scarce, and the need to protect these resources from overexploitation. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to ensure that fisheries continue to provide a critical ecosystem service for people and wildlife.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the proposed material lead to a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study reveals a previously unknown form of activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the adult CNS. These findings provide insights into the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system. They also suggest that the mammalian CNS may possess a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK pathway. This discovery may lead to the development of new regenerative therapies for the adult CNS.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a key component of the process of evolution. In this study, we use a population genomic approach to map recombination in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing 10 times more recombination than others. These regions are interspersed with regions of little or no recombination. We also find that recombination rates tend to peak near the start of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and may help us understand the evolution of recombination in plants and other organisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic, highly interconnected network of functionally specialized regions. The identification of these networks is a major goal of modern neuroscience. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting metabolic network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic activity in the dominant network during task performance. We found that the dominant network was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a direct link between the resting brain network organization and its functional role. It also provides a method for the assessment of network function in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of eukaryotic mRNA. It is essential for efficient translation and is conserved in all eukaryotes. The existence of 5′ modifications in bacteria has been known for decades, but the existence of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes has been controversial. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ modification in yeast, which we call nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes and the function of NAD-RNA.

We hypothesized that DNA methylation of specific loci in blood cells would be associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA methylation of specific loci in blood cells was associated with HbA1c in the DCCT, and that these loci were also associated with metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a baseline DNA-me profile of blood cells from people with diabetes, which can be used as a reference for future studies. This information can be used to develop new strategies for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. This information can be used to develop new strategies for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective treatment options. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBC tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The pathophysiology of this disorder is not fully understood, but it is considered to be a brain disorder. In this study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in plants. VOCs are important contributors to the overall aroma of fruits and vegetables, and their production is essential for fruit ripening and quality. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many VOCs are not known, and the production of some VOCs is highly variable among different species. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the known nitrogenous VOCs in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is essential for the production of VOCs in other closely related species of the tomato clade, and that it catalyzes the production of a unique class of VOCs. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in plants and will be useful for improving the flavor of tomato and other fruits and vegetables. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in the conservation and management of Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial navigation. It encodes the location of objects, people, and events in space, and it is the primary source of grid cells, which are thought to be the neural correlate of spatial navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves. These data provide a detailed picture of the organization of grid cells in the MEC and suggest that grid cells may be more specialized than previously thought. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of flowering regulation in plants. Understanding the mechanisms of flowering regulation may lead to the development of new strategies for the improvement of crop yield. Understanding the mechanisms of flowering regulation in dodder may lead to the development of new strategies for the control of this plant parasitic plant.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized type of nigral projection neuron that forms highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides insight into the structure and function of the dopamine system. It also has implications for the development of new treatments for Parkinson’s disease.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connecting with each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was driven by the speed at which people responded to their partners, not by the speed at which they responded to each other. This finding suggests that people are using the speed of their partner’s responses as a signal of connection. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by a unique morphology and physiology. SAN automaticity is regulated by a complex network of ion channels and stores that are activated by membrane depolarization and Ca2+ release. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by modulating the activity of ion channels and Ca2+ stores. These studies reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in the regulation of SAN automaticity. Our findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect was dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. We also show that Si priming of rice resistance was dependent on the expression of two key enzymes in JA biosynthesis, allene oxide synthase and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1, and that Si priming was associated with reduced expression of the Si transporter genes. These results suggest that Si priming of rice resistance against insect herbivores involves priming of JA-mediated defense responses and the promotion of JA biosynthesis by Si. Our findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activation of macrophages, which is important for the innate immune response. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings may help to understand the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and may provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, it is unclear how the brain maintains information over seconds and minutes. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of single neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to minutes. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for memory that is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

Nutrient loading from small streams is a major concern for the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small streams in driving coastal nutrient loads has not been quantified. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily N and P delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies, such as the Gulf of Mexico, to reduce the overall nutrient loads that threaten the health of coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the dynamics of the network are sensitive to the details of the environment, and that the system can exhibit a variety of behaviors, including a “saddle-node” bifurcation, depending on the details of the environment. This sensitivity to the environment is a hallmark of complex systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry render the brain susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We use a dynamic model of the cortical microcircuit to explain the effects of NMDAR-Ab on EEG and to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition, but only when the cortical microcircuit is critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other neuropsychiatric disorders on EEG. This framework may be useful for the development of new treatments for these disorders. (Show more)

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2, which is thought to be the result of anthropogenic emissions. However, the impact of this increase on the Earth system is not well understood. Here, we present a case study of a rapid global warming event that occurred during a previous period of rapid CO2 increase. We show that the warming was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and that the warming was driven by enhanced thermocline stratification. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the Earth system response to rapid CO2 increase in order to understand the impact of anthropogenic CO2 emissions on the system. This will require a better understanding of the Earth system response to abrupt warming events.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. We show that certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most plantations are too small to have a significant impact on deforestation. Certification also reduces active fire detection rates, but not forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Certification has no causal impact on deforestation in forests. These findings suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on deforestation in Indonesia.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal life, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus, which can be either male- or female-determining. In species with a single sex-determining locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of its parents, and the sex of an individual is either male or female. In species with multiple sex-determining alleles, the sex of an individual can be male, female, or intersex, and the sex of an individual can be male or female depending on the sex of its parents. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex-determining alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that multiple sex-determining alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex-determining alleles.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids, that are formed by the oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) vitamin A aldehyde adducts and subsequent photodegradation. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that RPE cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that Fe levels in the retina are elevated in a mouse model of age-related macular degeneration, and that Fe levels promote the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings suggest that Fe levels may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. In this study, we analyze the evolution of the feeding strategies of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use specialized tentacle structures armed with nematocysts for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialization is not a dead end, and that the evolution of morphological innovations can lead to the diversification of feeding strategies. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of predator specialization and morphological innovation, and help us to understand how the structure of food webs has changed over time.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure, and the evolution of its distinctive morphology and function has been a major focus of human evolutionary research. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the evolution of the modern human hand, with its distinctive morphology and function, is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 Mya, which provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive morphology and function of the modern human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus. This study highlights the importance of hominin hand fossils from the middle Pleistocene and early to middle Pleistocene time in general. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2 (SHMT1/2) that blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also report that the cancer cell-line screen revealed that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). We anticipate that dual SHMT inhibition will be a useful strategy for treating colon cancer, and that DLBCL will be a particularly sensitive model for SHMT inhibition. These findings will inform the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This work will also inform the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition and a growing number from overnutrition. This study shows that natural landscapes such as forests can play a role in improving people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study also shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets and thus on their health. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is based on the use of farm machinery, which has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
